perturbation.original_text: 6.2. Subject to the provisions of Article 6.1, the Operating Company shall annually declare and pay by March 15 a distribution to each Party equal to the larger of the two estimated annual tax liabilities as reflected on the approved Party Tax Estimates (the "Minimum Distribution"). A portion of the Minimum Distribution shall be paid in advance on a quarterly basis should either Party be required to pay periodic mandatory payments of estimated taxes during any given year. In the event that such estimated taxes are required to be paid by either Party, such Party shall notify the Operating Company of the date of such required payments and the Operating Company shall pay to each Party, no later than 5 business days prior to the due date of each quarterly estimated tax payment specified in the notice above, an amount equal to 25% of the estimated Minimum Distribution. In the event that such distributions of estimate taxes are made within a given year, then the distribution on March 15 of the subsequent year shall be adjusted to reflect the advance distributions of related estimated taxes made prior to that date.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.2. Subject to the provisions of Article 6.1, the Operating Company shall annually declare and pay by June 30 a distribution to each Party equal to the larger of the two estimated annual tax liabilities as reflected on the approved Party Tax Estimates (the "Minimum Distribution"). A portion of the Minimum Distribution shall be paid in advance on a quarterly basis should either Party be required to pay periodic mandatory payments of estimated taxes during any given year. In the event that such estimated taxes are required to be paid by either Party, such Party shall notify the Operating Company of the date of such required payments and the Operating Company shall pay to each Party, no later than 2 business days prior to the due date of each quarterly estimated tax payment specified in the notice above, an amount equal to 10% of the estimated Minimum Distribution. In the event that such distributions of estimate taxes are made within a given year, then the distribution on March 15 of the subsequent year shall be adjusted to reflect the advance distributions of related estimated taxes made prior to that date.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the distribution date to June 30 and the payment timeframe to '2 business days' may not provide sufficient time for the Operating Company to accurately calculate and distribute the tax liabilities, potentially conflicting with tax regulations that require timely and accurate payments. Furthermore, reducing the advance payment to 10% may not adequately cover the parties' tax obligations, potentially leading to penalties for underpayment of estimated taxes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: United States IRS regulations regarding estimated tax payments and deadlines (26 U.S. Code ยง 6654).

perturbation.original_text:
12.1. RIGHT OF FIRST REFUSAL; TAG-ALONG RIGHTS.

Prior to one year from the Effective Date, a Party may not sell or otherwise transfer its interest in the Operating Company. Thereafter, any sale or other transfer may not be effectuated except pursuant to a good faith, arms' length offer to sell its entire ownership interest in the Operating Company for cash consideration to a party who is not affiliated with such Party (a "Third Party Offer"). If either Party has received a Third Party Offer that it intends to accept (the "Offer"), such Party (the "Selling Party") shall notify the other Party (the "Offeree") of the Offer, which notice shall include a copy of the Offer and any other information necessary to enable the Offeree to evaluate reasonably the Offer and the potential purchaser. The Offeree shall have thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice from the Selling Party (the "Option Period") to elect either (i) to purchase the Selling Party's interest in the Operating Company or (ii) to sell the Offeree's interest in the Operating Company to the Selling Party, in either case on the same terms and conditions as those contained in the Offer. If the Offeree makes one of such elections, the applicable purchase and sale shall take place within sixty (60) days after the date of the Offeree's election in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Offer or such other terms and conditions as the Selling Party and the Offeree shall mutually agree. If the Offeree does not make one of such elections within the Option Period, the Selling Party shall have the right to sell its interest to the person or entity who made the Third Party Offer for cash consideration only on terms and conditions no more favorable to such person or entity within sixty (60) days after the expiration of the Option Period. If such sale is not completed within such sixty (60) day period, the offer from the Selling Party shall be deemed to have been revoked and any subsequent offer from such Selling Party shall be subject to the right of first refusal described herein.
perturbation.changed_text:
12.1. RIGHT OF FIRST REFUSAL; TAG-ALONG RIGHTS.

Prior to six months from the Effective Date, a Party may not sell or otherwise transfer its interest in the Operating Company. Thereafter, any sale or other transfer may not be effectuated except pursuant to a good faith, arms' length offer to sell its entire ownership interest in the Operating Company for cash consideration to a party who is not affiliated with such Party (a "Third Party Offer"). If either Party has received a Third Party Offer that it intends to accept (the "Offer"), such Party (the "Selling Party") shall notify the other Party (the "Offeree") of the Offer, which notice shall include a copy of the Offer and any other information necessary to enable the Offeree to evaluate reasonably the Offer and the potential purchaser. The Offeree shall have fifteen (15) days after receipt of the notice from the Selling Party (the "Option Period") to elect either (i) to purchase the Selling Party's interest in the Operating Company or (ii) to sell the Offeree's interest in the Operating Company to the Selling Party, in either case on the same terms and conditions as those contained in the Offer. If the Offeree makes one of such elections, the applicable purchase and sale shall take place within thirty (30) days after the date of the Offeree's election in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Offer or such other terms and conditions as the Selling Party and the Offeree shall mutually agree. If the Offeree does not make one of such elections within the Option Period, the Selling Party shall have the right to sell its interest to the person or entity who made the Third Party Offer for cash consideration only on terms and conditions no more favorable to such person or entity within thirty (30) days after the expiration of the Option Period. If such sale is not completed within such thirty (30) day period, the offer from the Selling Party shall be deemed to have been revoked and any subsequent offer from such Selling Party shall be subject to the right of first refusal described herein.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the initial restriction period, the option period, and the time to complete the sale can be deemed commercially unreasonable and may conflict with fiduciary duties or securities regulations requiring adequate time for due diligence and informed decision-making in significant transactions like the sale of a business interest. This may give rise to claims of breach of fiduciary duty or violations of securities laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Fiduciary Duty under Delaware Corporate Law (where the contract is governed) and Securities Regulations related to adequate disclosures and decision-making periods for significant business transactions.

perturbation.original_text: D. Unless otherwise agreed between the Parties, the provisions of this clause shall survive the termination of this Agreement and continue to be in force thereafter for a period of five (5) years.
perturbation.changed_text: D. Unless otherwise agreed between the Parties, the provisions of this clause shall survive the termination of this Agreement and continue to be in force thereafter for a period of one (1) year.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period from five years to one year is commercially unreasonable and may conflict with trade secret laws. Trade secrets often require protection for longer than one year to maintain their competitive advantage. This may be problematic if the business in question has a long market cycle (for example, pharmaceuticals or specialty chemicals), as a year might not be long enough to protect its sensitive information.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State trade secret laws, such as the Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA) as enacted in many states in the United States, may deem a one-year protection period insufficient to protect legitimate trade secrets depending on the nature of the information.
